Active users are more demanding. Users that engage in more complex transactions may generate more value to the organization, but also put more pressure on the system (e.g., transactions that involve multiple pages and integration points).  

Expensive transactions should be identified and tested.

name: Limits of testing
text_md:
"once you know where to look, it's simple to make a test that finds \[an error\]."

It's a "fantasy to expect every single bug (will be) driven out \[through testing\]. Bugs will happen. They cannot be eliminated, so they must be survived instead."  (Nygard, 2018)

name: Mission-critical systems
text_md: Mission-critical systems are those whose failure will result in an existential threat to the organization. "People have to go home for the day if they stop working".

name: System anti-requirements - Or what a system should NOT do
text_md: "Software design as taught today is terribly incomplete.  It only talks abut what systems *should* do.  It doesn't address the converse--what systems should *not* do.  They should not crash, hang, lose data, violate privacy, lose money, destroy your company, or kill your customers." (Nygard, 2018, p.1)

name: Agile development
text_md:
Agile development emphasizes 

- early delivery
- learning
- incremental improvement

"Production is the only place to learn how [a product] will respond to real-world stimuli"

name: Cone of uncertainty
text_md: At the beginning of a system development project, the team has less information upon which to make decisions, yet that is when some of the most consequential decisions need to be made.  Early decisions about a system's scope and component structure have a major impact on its whole evolution, and are the hardest to reverse at a later stage.

name: Validating responses from web services
text_md: "Treat a response as data until you've confirmed it meets your expectations. It's just text in maps (also called dictionaries) and lists until you decide what to extract."

name: Headless Drupal
text_md:
Decoupling back-end from front-end offers the ability for teams with specialized knowledge of modern front-end JavaScript frameworks to work in parallel with content management/creation teams, without compromising the integrity of the project. 

In this approach, Drupal is used to deliver content as a service, to be consumed on demand by other applications via web APIs.  Drupal handles the creation and management of structured content (including content workflows and user management), while other client apps flexibly handle the presentation of content and the creation of user experiences targeted at the needs of specific user groups.  

Drupal 8 offers a robust variety of features handling the encoding and serialization of API resources.  Drupal's API can accept HTTP requests and issue HTTP responses in JSON or XML to a client located in a decoupled application.

- The default REST API available out-of-the-box in Drupal 8 Core is REST-Compliant.  
- JSON API is a stable contributed module included in Drupal core that implements the RESTful API of the same name.
- GraphQL

There are, however, some disadvantages associated with the use of Drupal as a decoupled CMS.  This include: 

- Introduction of additional points of failure by introducing an additional hosting stack for front-end applications
- Need to handle client/front-end security
- Ability to immediately view live results while adjusting content not always available
- Ability to preview content in "review status" requires a separate staging environment
- Layout management is a developer's concern, not of the editor.

name: Drupal
text_md: Drupal is a free and open-source CMS, written in PHP and distributed under the GNU General Public Licence.  It was initially launched in 2001.

name: Content blobs vs content chunks
text_md:
- **Content blob**:  Big piece of unstructured content (including a mix of text, executable code, images, audio or other multimedia objects) that is published as a single entity within the body field of a design template. 

- **Content chunk**: "Small, defined \[piece\] of pure content, devoid of any presentational styling, and to which metadata can be assigned so computers can understand what \[it is\] about and how \[it relates\] to other chunks"

name: Separation between content and presentation
text_md: By separating the structuring and creation of content from the mechanisms used to deliver it to users allows to establish multi-channel publishing workflows and user experience catered to different audiences.

name: Web services
text_md: "REST with JSON over HTTP is the lingua franca for services today"

name: Subject analysis
text_md:
The analysis of an information resource in order to identify what it is about.  

Subject analysis is a matter of interpretation and depends both on the purpose at hand and on the available terms.

name: Designing for deployment
text_md:
Designing for deployment means to design a system in such a way that it will be possible to push frequent changes easily (e.g., to keep frameworks up-to-date and push security patches), without downtime and without breaking client applications. 

This requires, among other things, a versioning and backward-compatibility policy.

name: System stability
text_md: The stability of a system refers to its ability to continue operating without interruption. It is a prerequisite to any other concern.

name: Metadata schema
text_md: A set of rules specifying the attributes that can be used to describe an information resource.

name: Designing for production
text_md:
Today's data innovation projects require dealing with the complexity of modern production environments, including issues like:

- data virtualization
- containerization
- load balance
- service discovery

A system is said to be **"production ready"** when it is ready to be deployed, and to be run by independently by the operations team, facing real-world users and without the intervention of the development team. 

Designing for production means elevating production issues (such as security, runtime control, logging and monitoring, and connectivity) to be "first class concerns".  It considers operations teams to be primary users of the system, and seeks to address their needs from the beginning and not as an afterthought. 

"Software delivers its value in production (...) everything before production is prelude" (Nygard, 2018, p.6)

name: System transactions
text_md:
A transaction is "an abstract unit of work processed by a system" (not the same as a database transaction.  Transactions are "the reason the system exists".  

- A *dedicated system* processes only one type of transaction
- A *mixed workload system* processes different types of transactions.

name: System longevity
text_md:
The longevity of a system is its capacity to continue operating in production (processing user transactions) for a long time (e.g., "during the full length of time between code deploys").   

The main dangers to a system's longevity are (1) memory leaks and (2) data growth.  **Both are rarely caught during testing** ("applications never run long enough in the development environment to reveal their longevity bugs").

name: Resilience
text_md:
The resilience of a system is the degree to which (1) it can continue operating and enabling users to get work done under transient shocks, persistent stresses or component failures, and (2) it can quickly recover from unanticipated, severe failures.

"Software must survive contact with the real world"

Resilience is particularly important for mission-critical systems.

name: Mitigating the probability of a failure chain
text_md:
Every enterprise is "a mesh of interconnected, interdependent systems". Usually, the chain of events that leads to a catastrophic system failure are not independent from each other:  Sudden shocks and excessive strain may cause a component to fail.  And a failure in one part of the system may in turn cause strain to other parts of the system, increasing the probability of further component failures.

Every integration point is a potential point of failure propagation.  This is particularly a risk in the context of API-first application development. A **cascading failure** occurs when a crack in one layer triggers a crack in a calling layer. 

"It is impossible to predict and eliminate all possible bad events". The objective should be to contain the damage from individual failures in order to protect the rest of the system. 

Bad events are inevitable, but they must be survived. Some ways to mitigate the risk of cascading failures is to introduce timeouts, handshaking and decoupling middleware in all integration points.

name: Anti-patterns
text_md: "Common forces that have contributed to more than one system failure"

name: Every system's model is incomplete
text_md:
At any moment in time, our mental models of the systems we work with are wrong or incomplete, as real-world systems are complex, with many moving parts and internal dependencies. 

"Tightly coupled systems are the rule rather than the exception."

name: Tightly coupled systems are more prone to failure
text_md: "A highly complex system with many degrees of coupling offers more pathways for faults to propagate." Morover, "tight couplings accelerate the propagation of faults ... across system boundaries."

name: Lean concepts: Continuous improvement
text_md: Focus on what is valuable to the customer and then continuously improve the product over time

name: Data practice
text_md:
Data practitioners aim to derive value from data on two ends:

- **Data supply**: Collecting and generating data, making it ready to use by representing it, integrating it, storing it, and making it accessible to users.

- **Data use**: Building descriptive, predictive or analytic solutions

name: User stories
text_md:
User stories are a "note" to have a future conversation.  Their purpose is to get the planning process started, by helping the team ask the right questions and stay focused on value delivery. 

A user story is a non-technical, short description of a feature, written in the language of the customer.

name: Lean concepts: Respect for people
text_md: Emphasize people over process; respect people and trust them to deliver high-quality work

name: Personal time management in agile
text_md: Each person has their own time box (no more than eight hours work per day). Overtime work disrupts teams predictability and is not sustainable.  A team member cannot commit to a delivery date if there is too much work in process, if meetings are too many or too long, or if everyone is working overtime.

name: Chief Data Officer
text_md:
- Accountable for the quality of an organization's data
- Responsible for facilitating data access
- Tasked with building an efficient data governance

name: Code management - good practices
text_md: - Never hard-code credentials. Use a secrets file or config file that is .gitignored, or prompt the user.

name: Overview of Agile principles
text_md:
- Change is welcome (Principle 2)
- Progress is measured in terms of continuous delivery (Principles 3 and 7)
- Developers and customers work closely together (Principle 4)
- Small, motivated team of generalists are self-organized (Principles 5 and 11)
- Face-to-face interaction is maximized (Principle 6)
- High-value work is prioritized (Principles 1, 8, 9, and 10)
- Process improvement is discussed frequently (Principle 12)

name: Thinking like an agile team
text_md:
- Ask tough questions about the way they work and be open about continuous improvement.  
- Don't focus only on the practices.  Focus on the **why** of these practices.
- Embrace changing requirements and experimentation
- Emphasize having the right conversations, not so much having the right format
- Think in terms of products instead of projects

name: Cross-functional teams
text_md:
The production of increasingly complex software and knowledge products, requires the collaboration of multiple hyper-specialized individuals. It is nearly impossible for everyone in a team to be equally skilled in all functional areas involved, or to find project managers who understand all the different specialties involved in the delivery of the organization's products and services. 

In cross-functional teams:

- Everyone strives to be *good enough* so as to be able to contribute *something* to every bit of the team's work
- Each person focuses on the work that needs to be done, and not on their functional role
- Everyone seeks to spread expertise across the team through cross-training (everyone invents some of their time time in training and learning from others)
- Everyone is able to ask challenging questions about the product

By having cross-functional teams, the need for hand-offs and backups is minimized. Each team member has to train others in his or her own area of expertise, to ensure that the team can deliver value at a predictable, sustainable pace.

name: Cone of uncertainty
text_md:
Our knowledge of what it takes to deliver a product increases as we near the final stages of production.  Therefore, many of the decisions that are made at the start of a project will need to be revised later on, as more is learned about the product, the process, the client, etc. 

On the other hand, decisions are usually more expensive to change the more time has passed since they were made. 

**Delaying decisions to the "latest responsible moment"**
The objective is to make *just enough* early decisions so the work can get started, while keeping as much flexibility as possible.

name: Data security
text_md:
Data security refers to the safeguards that are in place to ensure that no data is lost, and tha it is not used for unauthorized purposes.  This includes, inter alia:

- User identification and authentication
- Encryption of data for transmission
- Access controls to data storage systems
- Security audits

name: Data protection
text_md:
Data protection refers to:

- Safeguards to ensure that data are handled in a way that avoids disclosure thorughout all the stages of the statistical production process
- Compliance with confidentiality pledge to respondents

name: Survey design
text_md:
- Target population
- Sampling plan
- Data collection instrument and methods
- Realistic time table
- Cost estimate

name: Survey documentation
text_md:
The documentation of a survey should help users understand how to:

- Properly analyze the data
- Replicate the results
- Evaluate the results

name: Coding qualitative data
text_md: Adding codes or tags to qualitative text data

name: Survey planning
text_md:
Survey planning should specify:

- Goals and objectives
- Potential users
- What decisions the survey is designed to inform
- What will be the key variables to be estimated 
- What statistical outputs (tabulations and analytic results) will be produced
- Related and previous surveys
- Steps taken to prevent unnecessary duplication with other sources

name: Notifying potential survey respondents
text_md:
Potential survey respondents need to be notified of:

- Survey rationale: Why is the information being collected, and how it will be used?

- Authority: Whether the responses are voluntary or mandatory.

name: Innovation and data sharing
text_md: "Data innovation is only possible if data is shared with as many people as possible"

name: Catalogs
text_md: "A roomful of books is not a library.  The catalog provides the library user with a simplified representation of the materials in the library collection," one "which enables the user to move from the record to the actual object described by the record."

name: Data catalog
text_md:
A data catalog is a metadata management tool designed to help data users find, understand, access and use datasets efficiently.  It allows users to explore data autonomously, providing information about its context, quality and use cases.  

Data catalogs enable data sharing.  

A data catalog typically includes the following functionalities:

- Search engine (all the catalogued datasets are indexed and searchable)
- Mechanisms to access the datasets
- Ability to tag / categorize datasets using both standardized and custom taxonomies and vocabularies 
- Tools for maintaining metadata using standardized metadata templates
- Ability to visualize links between multiple datasets
- Mechanisms for sharing and commenting on datasets

name: Semantic web applications
text_md:
Some possible applications of semantic web technologies include:

- Cross-referencing systems for easy navigation across information assets
- Knowledge organization systems consisting of a network of information assets
- Wiki platforms that support the creation of inter-connected knowledge assets

name: Data quality and data linkage
text_md: **Requirement 12.2** of the "National Quality Assurance Frameworks Manual for Official Statistics" calls all statistical databases to be "designed and arranged in a way that allows and facilitates data linkage, using unique identifiers for statistical units (...) while ensuring data security and privacy."

name: Assessing data quality - Steps
text_md:
1. Prioritize datasets to assess:  Identify which data has the most impact on the statistical process

2. Determine quantitative and qualitative indicators to measure different dimensions of quality - so different data quality policies and objectives are transformed into specific requirements

3. Decide how to measure each indicator and how often

4. Obtain and analyze data on quality indicators

5. Identify issues by order of importance, based on their frequency or their impact

6. Develop hypotheses on possible root causes (e.g., using a cause-effect diagram)

7. Identify and implement actions as part of a continuous improvement effort

name: Self-management: Change the narrative
text_md:
- **Reverse lens**: "What would the other person in this conflict say and in what ways might that be true?"
- **Long lens**: "How will I most likely view this situation in six months?"
- **Wide lens**: "Regardless of the outcome, how can I learn and grow from it?"

name: Sprint
text_md:
Time-boxed (weekly to monthly) iterations of work that deliver something of value to the customer. 

Sprints have always fixed start and end dates, and are generally of the same duration.  

No goal-altering changes are permitted during a sprint

Working in short, regular sprints eliminates uncertainty by delivering value predictably every few weeks.

name: Collaboration and decentralization
text_md: Collaboration is about decentralized decision making - so people closest to the work make the decisions.

name: Anti-patterns
text_md:
An anti-pattern is the opposite of a design pattern: "a proven flawed technique that will most likely cause some trouble and cost time and money. (...) A priori, it seems like a good idea, but in the end it will most likely cause more harm than good."

Some examples of anti-patterns include:

- **God class**: A class that handles too many things, and breaks the application every time someone touches it.

name: Command and control
text_md: A command-and-control organizational culture is based on a clear hierarchy  where people at the top make decisions and direct how work is to be executed by those under their supervision.  In this setting, everyone knows who they work for and who works for them, and predictability of projects with clear scope, budget and schedules is highly valued.

name: Backward-compatibility principle
text_md: Everything that worked in a particular way in the past should still work at least in that particular way after changes are made to a system.

name: Writing high-quality code
text_md:
Characteristics of high-quality code:

- **Flexibility**
- **Reusability**
- **Maintainability**
- **Readability**: Less code is simpler to visualize, leading to quicker undrestanding.  Use descriptive names for variables and methods. 
- **Simplicity**: Aim to write code that solves the issue at hand, instead of over-engineering it
- **Testability**

## Code smells:

A code smell is an indicator of a possible problem. For example:

- **Too many comments**: This is often an indication that the code could be split into smaller chunks with proper names, leading to better readability. 

- **Long methods**: More than 10 to 15 lines of code suggests a method (1) contains complex logic intertwined in multiple if statements, (2) does too many things, and/or (3) contains duplications of code.

- **Names that are not self-explanatory**: When the name of an element does not immediately suggest what it is about, it is likely that the element could be split into smaller multiple pieces.

name: How the web works
text_md:
- A client sends an *HTTP request* to a server, and then the server responds to that client.

- The most commonly used HTTP methods are GET and POST.  

- An HTTP request is composed of a *header* and an optional *body*. 
  - The HTTP header consists of key-value pairs representing metadata that the client wants to send to the server (e.g., including cookies)  
  - GET requests do not allow to include a body.  

- When the server decides to respond to the request, it returns a *header* and an optional *body* as well. The first line of the response indicates the status of the request. 

- **HTTP is stateless**: After this cycle is completed, the server is no longer aware of the client, and if the client sends another request, the server is not aware that it responded to a request earlier from that same client. 

- There are mechanisms, such as cookies, that enable a server to become "aware" of its clients,  creating a sense of persistence between their requests.

name: Design Patterns
text_md:
A design pattern is proven technique that can be sued to solve a specific problem.  

Design patterns help craft solutions at scale.

name: Interface
text_md: An interface is a "contract" that defines the behavior that a consumer can expect from a system, irrespective of how that behavior is implemented in the background.

name: Testing code
text_md:
Testing is an integral part of the development process.  If developers have any difficulties consuming their own code when creating tests, then most likely everyone else will also have difficulties using the code.  

** Testing good practices**:

- Avoid writing useless tests
- Keep the test suite healthy by adding missing test cases and removing obsolete or useless tests
- Think in terms of use case coverage, instead of how many lines of code are covered by the tests
- Automate tests as much as possible (running manual tests becomes tedious, time-consuming and error-prone as applications grow).  

**Types of tests**

1. **Unit tests**: Tests that focus on individual/atomic methods.  They should not rely on any infrastructure (such as a database); should be fast and test a specific code path only.  

2. **Integration tests**: Tests that focus on the interaction among components, e.g., what happens when a component queries a database, or when two components interact with each other.  Integration tests often involve some infrastructure. 

3. **Functional tests**: Tests that focus on testing the whole application, from a user's perspective.

name: Test-driven development
text_md:
Test-driven development (TTD) is a method of developing software in which tests are written before the actual code.  This helps developers understand how software should work before they start coding. 

TTD can be implemented using the `Red-Green-Refactor` technique:

1. Write a failing test (**red**)
2. Write just enough code to make the test past (**green**)
3. **Refactor** the code to improve the design while ensuring that all the tests are still passing

name: Refactoring
text_md:
Refactoring is a process of improving existing code without changing its behavior.  It helps clean the code base of a project and get rid of some technical debt. 

Refactoring is particularly important in agile development: Instead of trying to finish the product at once, it is refined and improved over time.  

Refactoring time must be factored into the planning of work (e.g., into product/sprint backlogs if using an Agile approach to project management).

name: Technical debt
text_md:
Technical debt consists of "all the corners that are cut during the development of a feature or system." While it is unavoidable to incur in technical debt in every project, it is important to manage it and to keep it within limits;  otherwise, it will not be possible to pay it back. 

Some ways to manage and limit technical debt include: 

- Refactoring often
- Learning to cooperate with all stakeholders involved in the project
- Using proper governance and management techniques

name: Embracing change
text_md: Applications are born to change.  It is important to remain flexible.

name: Interface segregation principle
text_md:
It is better to have multiple, smaller client-specific interfaces instead of  one large, general-purpose interface. 

Cohesion - The elements of an interface should align towards a common goal.

Smaller interfaces are easier to re-use, and help expose only the features that are needed for a specific purpose. They are also easier to compose into bigger pieces.

name: Cooperation is essential to manage technical debt
text_md: Form time to time, it may be necessary to cut short the usage of best practices in order to meet short-term constraints, such as deadlines, budgets, etc.  To ensure that the resulting technical debt is properly managed, everyone involved must learn to cooperate and to understand each other's reality, and agree on how to allocate time and resources to re-factor existing solutions as soon as possible.

name: Web service
text_md:
A web service enables a client to call a pre-formatted data message "on demand" from a source, using open standards such as HTML, XML, JSON, REST and SOAP. 

A web service API allows for machine-to-machine communication among web servers, or among web servers and clients.  They are "the conduit through with data travel on its way from the server to the consumer".

name: IT and data quality
text_md:
**Requirement 11.4** of the "National Quality Assurance Frameworks Manual for Official Statistics" calls for the application of modern information and communication technologies to improve the effectiveness and efficacy of statistical processes. 

- This requirement underlines the importance of having an **IT strategy, architecture and infrastructure** that are regularly reviewed and updated, wiht a view to continuously identify possibilities for innovation and modernization.  
- Moreover, it underlines the value of **automating routine clerical operations** and statistical processes such as data capture, coding, editing, validation and exchange). 
- Finally, it emphasizes the benefits of **pooling IT resources and investments** across different areas of a statistical organization.

name: Central IT and methodological services
text_md: Centralized IT and methodological units allow to pool resources and investments

name: Automation of routine statistical processes
text_md:
Modern information and communication technologies can be used to improve performance of statistical processes through automation. 

For example, routine clerical operations and statistical procedures (including ETL operations and and validation of data inputs and outputs) should be standardized and automated as much as possible.

name: Modernization of statistical operations
text_md: Current methods for data collection and dissemination are not keeping pace with information technologies and increasingly interlinked information systems.

name: Data dissemination policy
text_md:
Data dissemination is "the ultimate objective of a statistical system", and statistical organizations need to develop and implement a coherent data dissemination policy that enables them to "supply the right data to the right audience in the right format".   Such data dissemination policy should include:

- The **portfolio of statistical products** that will be targeted at different **user groups**
- The **media** in which statistical data and information are delivered (e.g., paper-based or digital products and services). 4
- The **distribution channels** for delivery aof those statistical products an services
- The appropriate **timing** for release of statistical products
- The model of communication (e.g., one-to-one vs. one-to-many)
- The use of **data visualization and communication tools** (e.g., story telling)

The data dissemination policy needs to be regularly reviewed an updated, to respond to changes in user needs, technology, etc.  To this end, statistical organizations should **monitor the effectiveness of their data dissemination policy** through a set of well defined indicators (e.g., use statistics of online products derived from Google analytics).

name: Proliferation of data portals
text_md: A common problem is the proliferation and lack of integration of multiple data portals with similar functionalities. This leads to duplication of work, as well as to confusion among users.

name: Public right to access official statistics
text_md: The public at large should have access to the same information reported to regional and international agencies

name: Statistical data reporting
text_md:
Reporting by statistical agencies to international monitoring agencies often follows specific reporting requirements and formats.

The International Monetary Fund's General Data Dissemination System (GDDS) Special Data Dissemination system (SDDS) are standards for National, regional and international reporting.

name: Organizational culture
text_md:
The organizational culture is what gives meaning to the work that people do in an organization.  It includes:
- Shared sense of roles and hierarchy
- Belief system
- Values
- Expectations

A strong culture enables an organization to maintain focus in a time of crisis.

name: Statistical organizations' threats and challenges
text_md:
Threats

- Rigid processes and methods
  - Process and methodology changes are time consuming and expensive 
  - Inability of statistical frameworks, standards and classifications to remain relevant to modern information needs
- Inflexible aging technology environments and legacy systems
- Quickly changing information needs
- Pressure to reduce provider burden 
- Inability to attract and retain critically skilled staff in a competitive market
  - The skill-sets that underpin statistical organizations are becoming increasingly valuable in the wider market, making it difficult for statistical organizations to compete to attract and retain these skills.

Challenges:

- Make richer use of existing information sources
- Increase use of administrative data and alternative data sources
- Enhance data interoperability across systems

name: Data validations
text_md:
Some automatic data validations tests may include:

- No duplicates in primary key
- No orphan foreign keys
- Only valid values within each field
- All values in a field comply with formatting rules
- Values of various field are consistent with each other

name: Response rates
text_md:
Information on unit and item response rates help assess whether the survey results are representative of the target population.

Response rates need to be measured, reported, and analyzed

name: Knowledge assets
text_md: "Statistical organizations deal with knowledge assets that aren't visible in the same way as physical or financial assets."

name: Quality and integration of administrative and other data sources
text_md:
**Requirement 13.4** of the "National Quality Assurance Frameworks Manual for Official Statistics" calls statistical agencies to promote the sharing, linking, and use of administrative and other data sources to minimize respondent burden, including by:

- Creating and sharing documentation about the quality and other characteristics of those data
- Developing and implementing technical tools for sharing and linking them, while protecting data confidentiality
- Promoting them as an alternative to survey-based data

name: Quality and the integration and standardization of statistical production systems
text_md: **Requirement 11.6** of the "National Quality Assurance Frameworks Manual for Official Statistics" calls statistical agencies to define, promote and implement integrated and standardized production systems, including through  the promotion, sharing and implementation of standardized solutions that increase effectiveness and efficacy.  It also calls for them to adopt a statistical business architecture based on international standards and tools, such as GSBPM, GAMSO, CSPA, and SDMX.

name: Data quality assessment roadmap
text_md:
- Set a timetable for developing and implementing a data quality assessment strategy
- Describe the data quality principles and policies to be used across the organization. 
- Secure commitment to data quality by senior management and key stakeholders
- Establish governance framework for data quality, including roles and responsibilities around data quality management
- Describe main statistical production processes within the organization (e.g., using the phases of the Generic Statistical Business Process Model, or GSBPM, as a reference)
- Identify and describe the structure, definitions, attributes and inter-relationships of data inputs and outputs of each stage of the main statistical production processes (e.g., using the Generic Statistical Information Model, or GISM).
- Develop a Quality Assessment Framework for the organization, formulating for the each input and output of every stage of the main statistical production processes:
    - Relevant quality characteristics
    - Appropriate quality indicators
    - Methods and sources of data for compiling quality indicators 
- Provide training and develop guidelines for implementing data quality assessment framework across the organization
- Compile and report quality indicators on a continuous basis
- Analyze information from quality indicators
- Identify necessary actions to improve quality of statistical processes and outputs (e.g., using the Generic Activity Model for Statistical Organizations, or GAMSO)

name: Lean concepts: Quality at the source (Jidoka)
text_md:
"Lean teaches us that quality inputs lead to quality outputs.  Focus on inputs allows for actionable metrics and direction for continuous improvement. (...)  

A by-product of lean's overall drive for continuous improvement is teamwork, as "the borders around responsibility and blame fade quickly when each person strives for improvement".

name: Quality of statistical information
text_md:
Quality of statistical information refers to the degree in which statistical products and services satisfy the needs and requirements of their intended users.  

The measurement of quality of statistical outputs is made operational through the specification of a set of indicators along various dimensions, which are often referred to as a "Data Quality Assessment Framework".    

This dimensions and indicators of such a framework usually include:

- **Relevance**: Extent to which the information content of the data delivered is pertinent to help users attain their own goals more effectively.

  - *Indicators of relevance may include:*
    - References in media
    - Number of website hits
    - Proportion of records pertaining to statistical units outside the target population
    - Proportion of units in the target population that are not represented in the dataset

- **Accuracy**: The closeness of a statistical data point or data set to the true value or set of values that it is intended to measure.  

  - *Indicators of accuracy may include:*
    - 
    - Proportion of correct predictions among the total number of cases examined
    - Average size of (ex-post) prediction errors among the total number of cases examined

- **Reliability**: The degree in which the same overall data generation process or method can be expected to yield the same results in repeated trials.  In situation where multiple revisions of an estimate are published over time, reliability can be thought of as the closeness of the initial estimate to the subsequent estimated values. 

  - *Indicators of reliability may include:*
    - Sample size relative to population size
    - Standard deviations 
    - Standard error estimated using a resampling method (e.g., bootstrap or jackknife estimation)
    - Number and size of subsequent revisions

- **Coherence and comparability:**  Degree to which two data points (or two datasets) can be assumed to be the result of the same overall data generation process, thus allowing to meaningfully combine them for analytic purposes.  In other words, for two data points (or data sets) to be deemed coherent and comparable, the assumptions made about the respective processes that generated them should not stand in contradiction to each other in any significant way.  For statistical data, coherence and comparability require in particular the use of common standards with regard to the concepts, definitions, classifications, and methods employed in their collection, processing, and dissemination.

  - *Indicators of coherence and comparability may include:*
    - Relative size of discrepancies in spatio-temporal trends exhibitied between two or more datasets that provide the same or similar information on the same subject matter
    - Whether or not to datasets use the same concepts, definitions, and classifications (e.g., same definition of statistical units; common sampling frameworks; same definition of geographic areas and reference time periods; same temporal frequency and geographic granularity; same definition of age groups; etc.) 

- **Timeliness**: Extent to which the statistical information pertaining to the measurement of a past phenomenon or event is delivered in time for users to be take meaningful action or make consequential decisions.

  - *Indicators of timeliness may include:*
    - Gap between publication date and reference period

- **Punctuality:** Degree to which statistical information is delivered according to an initially announced publication schedule.

  - *Indicators of reliability may include:*
    - Gap between actual and planned publication dates

- **Completeness**: Degree to which the data set includes all the relevant information expected by the user.
  - *Indicators of completeness may include:*
    - Number of records that are missing key variables
    - Total percentage of empty cells
    - Proportion of statistical units in the target population that are not represented in the data set
    - Proportion of statistical units in the sample design for which information is available / Response rates

- **Accessibility:** Ease with which users can find and obtain the statistical data in a ready-to-use format and in line with open data standards.

- **Interoperability**:  Ease with which a data set can be ingested and handled by multiple, independent, standard-compliant data processing and analysis systems. 
  - *Indicators of data security and confidentiality may include:*
    - Use of standard classifications, concepts and definitions
    - Use of open, machine-readable data formats and serializations


- **Clarity:** Extent to which the statistics are presented to users in an understandable manner and in a form that facilitates its proper interpretation and use. 
  - *Indicators of data security and confidentiality may include:*
    - Availability of complete and easy-to understand reference metadata (including glossary and methodological notes)
    - Use of meaningful, human-readable variable names


- ** Security and confidentiality:** Effectiveness with which the integrity of the data is preserved and the risks of disclosing confidential information about individuals, households and businesses are mitigated.

- **Compliance with applicable legal requirements**:


User satisfaction surveys are one means to collect data on quality indicators.

**Relationship between dimensions of quality of statistical information:**

- **Accuracy vs reliability**:  When there is a systematic bias in the data production process, then increasing the sample size will generally increase reliability but will not improve accuracy.

name: Total Quality Management
text_md: Total Quality Management is the systematic and ongoing monitoring and identification of quality issues across an entire organization, as well as the planning and implementation of corrective actions, aimed to maintain and continuously improve over time the quality of the all the products and services delivered to its customers.

name: Quality
text_md:
Quality is the degree to which the characteristics of a product or service meet the needs of its users.  

Since different users have different, multiple needs that must be balanced against each other, a practical analysis of quality must break this definition down into multiple dimensions, so as to address different, but inter-related and often conflicting, types of user needs.

name: Evolutionary architecture
text_md: The product owner and development team should plan from the beginning for the growth and continuous development of the system after its first release.  The objective should be to build a systems architecture that can grow and adapt to changing needs and conditions over time.

name: Importance of architecture decisions
text_md: "Design and architecture decisions are also financial decisions" (p.4)

name: Ivory-tower architecture
text_md:
Putting too much emphasis on "enterprise standards", imposing specific technologies on the team of developers, without listening to them or to the users. 

This is the opposite extreme of an "accidental architecture" situation. But is equally crippling.

name: Common Statistical Business Architecture Principles
text_md:
- **Holistic approach**: Ensure data, methods, technology and skills are consistent, re-usable and interoperable across multiple functions and business units in the organization.

- **End result focus**: Make the envisioned output the reference starting point for the design of new statistical processes.

- **Enterprise-level value**: Design and implement new or improved statistical business processes aiming to maximize value at enterprise level. Leverage all enterprise capabilities so that the end result is well integrated, measurable and operationally effective. 

- **Customer value**: Design statistical services that deliver value to end customers. 

- **Sustainability**: Make investments and plans aiming to maximize the long-term continuity, adaptability and growth of core statistical functions.

- **Re-use before designing new**: Re-use all existing capabilities and products before designing new ones.

- **Design new for re-use**: Design new capabilities and products to be re-used, making sure they can be easily standardized, assembled and adapted to accommodate changing demands.

- **Maximization of use of existing data assets**: Leverage all currently existing data before collecting additional data; monitor and reduce respondents' burden over time.

- **Standards**: Adopt open, industry-recognized and international standards where available.

- **Metadata-driven processes**: Design business processes to ensure that their composition, operation and management are metadata-driven and automated as much as possible.

- **Discoverability and accessibility**: Ensure that statistical services are easily discoverable and accessible to enable sharing and re-use.

- ** "Just-right" granularity**: Define statistical services at the level of granularity that is most relevant to the business needs.

- **Trust and security**: Conduct all business in a manner that builds trust and confidence in the statistical organization's decision making and practices and its ability to preserve the integrity, quality, security, and confidentiality of the data assets entrusted to it.

- **Service-level agreements**: Clearly define performance expectations for every statistical service, laying out metrics and remedies should agreed-on service levels not be achieved.

- **National and international partnerships**: Collaborate nationally and internationally to leverage and influence statistical and technological developments which support the sharing of statistical services.

name: Pragmatic architecture
text_md:
- Give due consideration to issues such as memory usage, CPU requirements, bandwidth needs, etc. 
- Focus on practical feasibility of proposed solutions
- Think in terms of the dynamics of gradual improvement
- Inspect the inner workings of any abstractions or frameworks and modify or eliminate them if necessary

name: Early and continuous integration
text_md:
Continuous integration is the practice of merging all developers' working copies of the code base to a shared main branch several times a day.

Integration and testing activities are crucial to verify whether components being developed in multiple parallel tracks meet customer expectations.   Continuous integration is critical to validate assumptions about how different components interface with one another and address any issues early on.

name: Extreme Programming (XP)
text_md:
An agile approach focused on software development whose practices include:

- continuous integration
- software refactoring
- test-driven development

name: Service-oriented architecture (SOA)
text_md:
A service is a business activity that generates a specific outcome. It is self-contained and can be re-used by a number of business processes within and across different organizations. 

Services can be classified according to their level of granularity:

- An atomic service encapsulates a fine-grained piece of functionality
- An aggregate service contains larger, more complex or composite functionalities

While aggregate services can be optimized to attain greater efficiency, fine-grained services allow greater flexibility for sharing and re-use.

name: Business Architecture: Functions, Processes and Services
text_md:
A **business function** is something that an enterprise does, or needs to do, to achieve its objectives. 

A **business process** is a sequence of steps required to perform one or more business functions.  Each step may be a sub-processes consisting of various steps. 

A **business service** provides a means for accessing a business function by performing one or more business processes.  It has a defined interface that delivers a specific output given a particular set of inputs.

name: Sustainable pace of work
text_md: People should be able to work at a pace that they can continue for an extended period of time

name: Fighting misinformation and conspiracy theories
text_md:
"It's undeniable that we face ongoing battles against misinformation, on subjects from COVID-19 to climate change, from vaccines to votes." What can be done "to convince people to rethink their positions on fake news and propaganda'?

Discussing and exposing the common mechanisms behind the spread of misinformation, such as (1) use of a false authority figure, (2) appeal to an individual's anger and prejudices, (3) claim of urgency.  Promote "active open-minded thinking". 

"People who are educated to recognize how misinformation spreads are less likely to be duped by it, or to spread it themselves".

name: Avoiding unnecessary formalities
text_md:
Agility is value-centric, as opposed to document-heavy or process-centric.  "Process for the sake of process is a type of waste".

Intermediate artifacts such as development plans and process documentation do not provide any direct value to the customer.  Their value depends on whether they contribute to deliver a working product to customers. 

Examples of unnecessary formalities:

- A three-day, heavyweight process is required for approving and migrating code from the development environment to the QA environment before we are allowed to start testing. 

- All anomalies have to be logged into a excel worksheet so that they can be tracked and reported, even if I could just tap on the shoulder of the person sitting next to me and say, “Hey, this isn’t working; could you fix it?” and have him make a fix so I can continue my work. 

- I write a document because now is the prescribed time to write that document, even though nobody can say why that document is necessary or valuable.

name: Quality testing is a continuous task
text_md:
Quality is not something that should be delegated to a "test team" at the end of the process.  

Quality should be owned by the whole cross-functional team, and be continuously built in and verified in every iteration of the product.

name: Being fast vs. being hurried
text_md:
The outcome is enhanced with speed.  However, hurrying with the intent of getting things done substantially reduces effectiveness.  High-performance teams move swiftly, nimbly and deliberately while carving out enough time for inspect-and-adapt activities along the way. 

The objective is to deliver small increments quickly, in order to obtain feedback fast and to get value into the hands of the customer sooner.  

The point of velocity in agility is the ability to learn and react quickly.

name: Transitioning to Agile project management
text_md:
Agile is radically different from how most organizations operate.  in order to transition to an agile way of doing things, there needs to be a cultural change and a re-alignment of roles and responsibilities.  

**Identify key supporters**

Get the right people on board, including individual contributors form different functional areas, their managers, and a senior executive who can sponsor an agile pilot project.  These should become a team of supporters who see the value in the agile transition and are willing to try it. 

Discuss with them the benefits of embracing an agile mindset. and how the agile principles and values can enhance delivery and predictability in the organization.  

**Implement agile training and couching**

Ensure there are training and couching opportunities for everyone in the organization to learn about the values, principles, and practices of the agile mindset.   

**Focus on organizational culture**

Help people become comfortable with sharing and collaborating, explaining that when people learn more about what others do, and have an opportunity to collaborate with others outside their fields of expertise, everyone grows their own skills.  

**Select and pilot project**

In order to transition from traditional to Agile project management, it's a good idea to select a medium-sized pilot project.  This will allow to test the agile fundamentals from start to finish and gather feedback on areas where the organization will need to change current practices. 

The project should run for 4 to 12 weeks, involve all roles and cover all phases of development.  Moreover, it should not be a high-risk project, 

**Bottom-up vs. Top-down transformation**

Bottom-up transformation is usually faster, but may lead to issues id there is lack of senior management support. Top-down transformation may be challenging when teams do not know much about the agile mindset.

**Building the business case and secure funding **

One of the main challenging aspects of an agile transformation effort is building the business case and securing funding for a project with flexible scope, which often goes against traditional way of doing things.

name: An agile approach to measuring progress
text_md:
The agile way of measuring progress is by delivering working, validated assets to the customer, not by whether we are proceeding according to a per-defined plan. 

Finishing on time and on budget according to a per-specified plan is not a measure of success; the true measure of success is the amount of customer-valuable work that is delivered (value-centric delivery)

"A project in production can be a failure.  Delivering a product does not guarantee success."

name: Idle work vs idle workers
text_md: Finding and eliminating bottlenecks in the workflow is more effective than trying to keep everyone 100% busy.    Idle work is far more wasteful and economically damaging than idle workers.  Work delays (which keep value from being delivered to the customer) can be more expensive than the cost of having a buffer of some sub-utilized staff / team members at any point in time (and according to queue theory, delays grow exponentially once available resources and staff reach 100% utilization).

name: Work in Progress (WIP)
text_md:
Work in Progress is work that has been started but is not yet finished.  The inventory of work in progress is a critical variable agile management.  The focus should be on reducing idle work and establishing a steady workflow.  

The cost of change is higher when there is too much work in progress. 

The benefits of working in smaller batches include:

- Smaller amounts of work are waiting to be processed 
- Reduced flow variability
- Accelerated feedback
- Less impact of errors
- Reduced complexity
- Increased focus and sense of responsibility

name: Short feedback loops
text_md: Fast feedback closes the learning loop quickly and allows to truncate bad development paths before they can cause serious economic damage.  Errors compound when we delay feedback, resulting in exponentially larger failures. The longer we validate assumptions, the greater the number of risky dependencies built into the product.  On the other hand, fast feedback allows to quickly uncover and exploit time-sensitive opportunities.

name: Adaptability vs. up-front planning
text_md:
Project teams need to balance the need for up-front planning (predictive work) against the need for adaptability.  

Up-front planning should be helpful without being excessive.   Lack of any planning leads to a state of constant, chaotic change.  But too much predictive planning creates sunk costs that limit adaptability to new circumstances or new information.  (It is cheaper to make changes in plans sooner than later). 

Requirements, designs, test cases, etc should be produced "just in time", keeping all options open until the last responsible moment (when the cost of not making a decision exceeds the cost of making a decision). The idea is to avoid rushing to make decisions that are difficult to reverse, and instead gathering as much information as economically feasible while avoiding costly delays in delivering value to customers.  

In other words, the goal is to keep the cost-of-change curve flat for as long as possible by limiting the volume of started-but-not-yet-finished work.  Important decisions should not be delayed for ever, but if possible should be broken down into smaller decisions, some of which can wait until more information is available to validate any underlying assumptions.

name: Reducing requirements uncertainty thorugh probing and exploration
text_md:
At the beginning of any project, many requirements are specified without sufficient knowledge about the desired features of the final product, the means to achieve them, or even knowledge of who the final customer is (low-quality requirements). 

It's impossible to get all the requirements right up front; and even if at the beginning of a project the requirements were perfectly specified, changes in the environment during execution can make them obsolete before value is delivered to the customer.

Agile teams try to specify just enough requirements up front so they can start building working solutions that allow them to obtain early feedback from stakeholders to fill-in the details, validate assumptions and learn about any unknown unknowns. Moreover, in the face of too much uncertainty, agile teams may choose to "learn by doing", building a prototype, creating a proof-of-concept model, performing a study or conducting an experiment.

name: Transparency in scrum
text_md: All relevant information must be available to the people involved in creating the product.  Transparency makes inspection possible, which is needed for adaptation.  Transparency also establishes trust.

name: Inspection and adaptation
text_md: It is important to inspect and adapt not only "what" we are building (product), but also "how" we are building it (process).

name: Iterative development
text_md: Teams usually get things wrong before they get them right, and initial results are often poor before they are good.  The number of iterations is not fixed from the beginning. but guided by feedback received after each iteration.

name: Cynefin Framework
text_md:
A framework that classify operations into 5 main types of environments:

- **Chaotic**:
  - *Strategy*: **Act -> Sense -> Respond**
  - *What is required*: Leadership and immediate action to quickly identify a practical solution, instead of trying to find the best solution.  
  - *Objective*: To stabilize the situation, re-establishing order and migrating to the "complex" domain as soon as possible
  - *Tools*: Kanban

- **Complex**:
  - *Strategy*: **Probe -> Sense -> Respond**
  - *What is required*: Creative / innovative approaches; a fail-safe environment for experimentation; intense interaction and communication
  - *Objective*: Discovering patterns and documenting emerging practices
  - *Tools*: Scrum, Kanban

- **Complicated**:
  - * Strategy*: **Sense -> Analyze -> Respond**
  - *What is required*: Investigating several options, applying good practices, using metrics and relying on experts
  - *Objective*: Gain insight and control; discover cause-effect relations
  - *Tools*: Six sigma

- **Simple**:
  - *Strategy*: **Sense -> Categorize -> Respond**
  - *What is required*: Assessing and categorizing the situation based on known facts; applying best practices
  - *Objective*: Implementing the optimal solution
  - *Tools*: Off-the-shelf solutions

- **Disorder**: Don't know in what environment we find ourselves

name: Product backlog
text_md:
The product backlog is a continuously updated list of prioritized, high-value features or items that are required to meet the product owner's vision.  

*Product Grooming*: Activity of creating, refining, estimating, and prioritizing the product backlog items. It starts by breaking down the envisioned product into a set of features that are prioritized. Items can be added, deleted or revised by the product owner as business conditions change or as the team's understanding of the product grows.

name: Daily scrum / daily standup
text_md:
A daily, timeboxed (15-minutes-or-less) meeting of the development team members, facilitated by the scrum master, to discuss:

- What did I accomplish since the last daily scrum?
- What do I plan to work on?
- What obstacles or impediments are preventing me from making progress?

This is a synchronization, inspection and adaptive planning activity; not a traditional status meeting, nor a problem-solving meeting.

name: Definition of done
text_md:
Baseline criteria to establish with confidence that the work completed is of good quality and potentially shippable

- For example: "A complete slice of functionality that is designed, built, integrated, tested and documented"

- In early, exploratory stages of a project, it could mean "a slice of functionality that is sufficiently usable to generate actionable feedback"

name: Agile approach
text_md:
Agile is an empirical approach for value delivery through team collaboration, based on a series of values, principles, practices and tools.

- Teams are cross-functional and self-organizing
- Upfront planning is limited to what is absolutely necessary to get the work started
- The starting point is a product backlog, and the team always works  in short, time-boxed iterations / increments, focusing first on the most important or highest-priority items
- At the end of each iteration:
  - The team delivers a potentially shippable product
  - The team reviews the completed features with the stakeholders to get their feedback
- Based on feedback, product owner and team can change priorities on what to work next and decide how to do the work
- There is no multi-tasking: everybody is focused on moving forward the same ball, minimizing hand-offs
- Teams strive to work at a predictable, steady and sustainable pace
- "Inspect and adapt" activities focus on continuous improvement, both of products and processes

name: Scrum practices
text_md:
Scrum practices include:

1. Roles:
    - **Product owner**:
      - Executes product leadership, deciding what features and functionalities will be developed and in what order
      - Maintains and communicates a clear vision of what the scrum team is trying to achieve
      - Makes sure that the most valuable work is always performed first
      - Is available to answer questions of the team as soon as they are posted
    - **Scrum master**:
      - Helps everyone understand and embrace scrum values, principles and practices
      - Protects the team from outside interference
      - Works to remove impediments that inhibit team productivity (when the team cannot reasonably resolve them)
      - Does administrative work necessary to make sure everyone in the team has what they need to do their work
      - Acts as a coach and leader during change-management process
      - Helps the team resolve issues and make improvements in their scrum
      - Facilitates self-management and guides the team in creating and following its own process
    - **Development team**:
      - Is responsible for designing, building, and testing the desired product
      - Self-organizes to determine the best way to deliver what the product owner has asked for

2. Activities
   - Product backlog grooming
   - **Sprint planning**:
      - At the beginning of each sprint, the product owner, the scrum master, and the development team must jointly determine the subset of product backlog items they believe can completed in the next sprint. They also agree on a sprint goal and commit to deliver a specific set of features, creating a sprint backlog. "Sprint planning results in both a forecast and a commitment."  This commitment helps build trust between the product owner and the development team, supports short-term planning and decision making in the organization, and enables teams to make decisions based on what other teams have committed to.
   - **Sprint execution**:
      - The development team, coached by the scrum master, performs all the task-level work specified in the sprint backlog.  Through daily scrum meetings, the team members help mange the flow of work. 
   - **Sprint review**:
      - Stakeholders and scrum team inspect the product being built in a scheduled meeting, where they inspect the product features just completed and discuss to guide and adapt forthcoming development efforts. It is also an opportunity to get a deeper appreciation of the business side needs and expectations.
   - **Sprint retrospective**:
      - After the sprint review, and before the next sprint planning meeting, the scrum team inspects the scrum process being used to create the product. As a result of the retrospective, the team identifies and commits to a practical number of process improvement actions for the next sprint.

3. Artifacts
   - **Product backlog**
   - **Sprint backlog**: Features of the product backlog that should be delivered by the end of the current sprint, broken down into more granular tasks, each of which has a detailed description and an effort-hour estimate.  

4. Rules
  - As a general rule, no changes in scope or personnel are permitted during the sprint
  - Sprints always have a fixed start and end date, and are generally of the same duration (in order to establish a cadence)

name: Value-based strategy
text_md:
>"Unless an initiative creates value for customers, employees or suppliers, it is not worth doing."  
> (Felix Oberholzer-Gee, 2021)

Organizations that focus on creating value for their customers, employees and suppliers perform better financially over time by:

- Demonstrating that the organization cares about their customers' best interest in every interaction, thus earning their trust and loyalty and increasing their "willingness to pay". 
- Attracting and retaining talent by make work more interesting and motivating to employees
- Helping suppliers reduce their operating cost or raise their productivity, thus reducing their "willingness to sell"

name: Scrum values
text_md:
- **Honesty**: Adherence to the facts, refusing to deceive others or oneself in any way. 

>*"Agile teams only agree to take on tasks they believe they can complete, so they are careful not to overcommit" and "are also honest when they need help".*

- **Openness**: Willingness to engage with others and to hear and consider different opinions. 

>*"When team members aren’t sure how work is going, they ask" and they "consistently seek out new ideas and opportunities to learn."*

- **Courage**: Self-confidence and moral strength to relentlessly expose any type of organizational dysfunction, waste and to learn from failure. 

>*"Scrum teams must feel safe enough to say no, to ask for help, and to try new things. Agile teams must be brave enough to question the status quo when it hampers their ability to succeed."*

- **Respect**: Recognition and appreciation of the intrinsic worth of the opinions and contributions of every team member and every stakeholder. 

>*Scrum team members know that "everyone has a distinct contribution to make toward completing the work of the sprint. They respect each other’s ideas, give each other permission to have a bad day once in a while, and recognize each other’s accomplishments."*

- **Focus**:  Continuous effort to avoid low-value distractions and direct everyone's attention and energy to what matters most.  

>*Scrum teams finish whatever they start and "are relentless about limiting the amount of work in process". *

- **Trust**: Reliance on the good faith, truthfulness, knowledge and skills of each other. 

>*"Scrum and agile teams trust each other to follow through on what they say they are going to do."*

- **Empowerment**: Ability of self-organizing teams to ask and answer their own questions and to define for themselves how to do the work necessary to meet project goals.

- **Collaboration**: Capacity of team members to effectively cooperate and assist each other in achieving a common goal. 

>*"Scrum teams work together as a unit."*

name: Scrum
text_md:
Scrum is an empirical **framework** consisting of values, principles and practices for organizing and managing work. Scrum is an agile approach for delivering high-quality products and services that maximize customer value in a timely and economical manner.  

It focuses on delivering smaller, more frequent releases that "give customers what they really want, not just features they might have specified on the first day when they knew the least about their needs."

"Scrum ... assumes that the process necessary to create the product is complex and therefore would defy a complete upfront definition."

It is an **empirical** framework, in the sense that continuously **inspects** results to derive lessons learned and **adapt** processes and practices.

name: Users of statistical data and their needs
text_md:
Statistical organizations must identify their key audiences / user groups and regularly assess and prioritize their data and information needs. 

The extent to which the needs of key user groups are met is the ultimate measure of every success of statistical organization, and thus needs to be monitored continuously and acted upon.

The Information and audience model of the UN Economic Commission for Africa identifies various user communities and their data requirements.   Broader audiences require data and information that are more aggregated and summarized (e.g., headline indicators and policy briefs). On the other hand, narrower/specialized audiences require detailed information and disaggregated data. 

Types of audiences:

- Decision makers 
  - Leaders from governmental, international, business, and civil society organizations
  - Public officials, managers
- General interest users
  - The general public
  - Students
- Specialists
  - Analysts
  - Researchers
  - Regulators

name: Akoma Ntoso
text_md: A standard for techology-neutral electronic representation of parliamentary, legislative and judiciary documents in XML format.   Provides XML schemas to model the structure and semantic components of digital documents.

name: Enterprise architecture skills
text_md:
Roles and responsibilities of a enterprise architect include:

- Evaluate the existing operating environment across the enterprise to identify redundancies, gaps and inefficiencies
- Working with stakeholders to facilitate the discovery and documentation of the customer’s business scenarios in order to understand real needs, as opposed to wants, and to translate them into business requirements
- Conceptualize technical solutions to complex problems and meet business requirements, developing well-formulated models of the components of these solutions.
- Verify stability, security, portability, scalability and interoperability, of the proposed enterprise architecture
- Evaluate and guide the selection of technologies to implement the proposed enterprise architecture.
- Collaborate with stakeholder to gain organizational commitments for all process, systems and application plans
- Communicate project information through presentations, technical reports, or white papers 

Different roles of an enterprise architect and a solution designer/ builder:

- The enterprise architect must remain at a a high level of abstraction, concentrating on the few critical components and their interfaces. 
- The solution designer/builder translates architecture into deliverable components.

name: Enterprise architecture
text_md:
An enterprise architecture is a framework (i.e., a set of principles and practices) for the integration of business processes, data, software applications and hardware infrastructure to achieve desired business results. 

It is composed of:

- **Business architecture:** Elements of the enterprise's business strategy, including business functions, processes and services ("What the enterprise does, why it is done, and how")
- **Data architecture:** Definition of the organization's data structures, data flows, and data storage and management principles and practices
- **Application architecture:** Principles and practices for selecting, designing and deploying software applications in accordance with business goals and processes
- **Technology architecture:** Description of all hardware, and IT infrastructure necessary to develop and deploy business applications.

An enterprise architecture "helps remove silos, improves collaboration [within] an organization and ensures that the technology is aligned to the business needs." 

Having a well-defined enterprise architecture enables an organization to transform its legacy processes and applications and to adapt to emerging technology trends.  

Other benefits of an enterprise architecture:

- Better collaboration between IT and business units
- Ability to prioritize IT investments
- Effective evaluation and procurement of IT solutions
- Common understanding of IT infrastructure and systems across all business units in the organization

An enterprise architecture addresses the entire organization in a holistic manner, instead of focusing on the needs and problems of individual business units.  It is akin to a "master urban plan" that provides the framework for a well-functioning city, beyond the "blueprints" specifying the design of a single building.  Following this analogy, one could say that the lack of an enterprise architecture leads to the proliferation of incoherent and inefficient solutions across the enterprise, similar to the effects of "unconstrained urban sprawl".

name: "Accidental architecture"
text_md:
Situation in which technical solutions are "built for a very specific purpose with little regard for ability to share information with other adjacent applications in the statistical cycle and with limited ability to handle simlar but slightly different processes and tasks."

"Historically, statistical organizations have developed their own business processes and IT-systems for producing statistical products. Although the products and the processes conceptually are very similar, the individual solutions are not" (https://statswiki.unece.org/display/CSPA/I.++CSPA+2.0+The+Problem+Statement)

name: Estimating size of features for product backlog
text_md:
Product owners need to know an item's cost to properly determine its priority.  

Scrum teams usually employ a relative size measure (e.g., story points or ideal days) to estimate the size of a product feature.

name: Common Statistical Production Architecture (CSPA)
text_md:
CSPA is a "reference architecture for the statistical industry", i.e., a set of **recommended patterns and approaches for the integration of business processes, applications, data, and IT infrastructure** for the creation and delivery of statistical products and services. 

- It covers all statistical production processes
- It does not prescribe a particular technology environment

CSPA defines a framework for common services for statistical production, providing savings opportunities for collaborative development, sharing and re-use across different statistical processes and across different organizations. 

A common statistical production architecture enables project managers, statisticians, IT specialists and other stakeholders **to collaborate and communicate effectively** about specific statistical productions projects and programmes.

By identifying patterns for the integration of technology and applications that have been successfully used across different statistical projects and organizations, CSPA helps teams **anticipate problems**,  **avoid errors and delays**, and **reduce costs**.

A common enterprise architecture approach within and across statistical organizations allows them to respond to emerging risks and challenges, and to leverage new opportunities, by facilitating the reuse and sharing of solutions and services and enhancing standardization and interoperability of statistical production systems and processes.

name: Reference architecture
text_md:
"A reference architecture is a document or set of documents that provides recommended structures and integrations of IT products and services to form a solution. The reference architecture embodies accepted industry best practices, typically suggesting the optimal delivery method for specific technologies."

"Reference architectures help project managers, software developers, enterprise architects, and IT managers collaborate and communicate effectively about an implementation project. A reference architecture anticipates—and answers—the most common questions that arise. As a result, they help teams avoid errors and delays that may occur without the use of a tested set of best practices and solution approaches."

name: Clarity Paradox: Success as a catalyst for failure
text_md:
Clarity of purpose >> Success >> More options and opportunities >> Diffused efforts >> Less clarity of purpose

Early success often leads to "the undisciplined pursuit of more." Thus, "one simple antidote is the disciplined pursuit of less... purposefully, deliberately, and strategically eliminating the nonessentials... constantly reducing, focusing and simplifying."

To avoid the clarity paradox, we need to keep a constant check on the Sisyphean task of clarifying purpose.  

At the personal level, it means continuously finding the intersection between the set of activities we are deeply passionate about, those in which we are genuinely talented, and those that meet a significant need in the world. 

We need to continuously 'figure out which ideas from the past are important and pursue those" while throwing out the rest.  

This means also a keeping a constant check on WIP (work in progress): "eliminating an old activity before (adding) a new one" so "you don't add an activity that is less valuable than something you are already doing".

name: Benefits from joining a community of practice
text_md:
Individuals and organizations who share valuable ideas through a community of practice can build their reputation and trustworthiness.   

The community of practice provides:
1. Access to multiple channels of informal cross-group communication 
2. Ability to connect with peers and potential partners from other organizations and occupational communities on a broad range of issues. 
3. The opportunity to obtain relevant "know-how" from a variety of perspectives

Individuals who do the same type of work in different jurisdictions can support each other when facing similar challenges, while individuals who have different roles can gain understanding of different viewpoints and find opportunities for cooperation.

In other words, the community of practice reduces the cost of knowledge sharing. 

Ultimately, an effective community of practice leads participants to "generate improvements in their own organizations, which can then be brought back to the community of practice, creating a cycle of learning and knowledge exchange for participants."

name: Application Programming Interface (API)
text_md:
An API consists of a set of methods and object classes that collectively describe the behavior of a system in response to specific actions by a user or client application. 

It abstracts the actual implementation of that behavior, exposing only the classes or methods that are required by the client to perform a task.

name: API-first
text_md: An approach in which web services are considered the most essential feature of a system, and in which the most important users are the consumers of those APIs.

name: Purpose of "collaborative" groups in official statistics
text_md:
Over the years, several "collaborative" groups and "working groups" composed by practitioners from national and international statistical organizations have been established with the objective of helping official statisticians address the challenges they face by:
  - Learning what peers do in similar situations
  - Seeking and sharing knowledge

"Belonging to an international community reduces individual risks for new developments through additional scrutiny and testing [and allows to] harness capacity from across the community to insulate individual statistical organizations from budgetary shock."  (By Thérèse Lalor, [Introducing CSPA!](https://statswiki.unece.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=112132835))

name: Need for knowledge sharing across organizations
text_md: No organization alone has all the knowledge it needs to attain its objectives.  This creates an incentive for reaching across organizational boundaries in search of knowledge. "The sharing of knowledge across organizations, particularly in the public sector, can lead to innovation, facilitate better problem definition, (...) reduce redundancies, build long-term collaborative capacity, and (...) increase accountability."

name: Coordination of National Statistical System
text_md:
The National Statistical Office plays a key role in coordinating the work of different stakeholders involved in the production, dissemination and use of official statistics in a country, so that their individual and collective actions contribute to deliver high-quality, trusted data that meet the information requirements of all sectors of society.

Proper coordination of the NSS requires:

- Clarity with regard to the roles and responsibilities of the various NSS members
